name: Dungeon Talk
description:
Dungeon Talk (DT) has been described as a hilarious mix of Dixit, Apples to Apples, Munchkin, and with a sprinkle of story telling fantasy RPG. DT can be learned in 5 minutes and played in under 30 minutes with endless replayability.

Dungeon Talk is a 2-6 player fantasy party game for family, adults, and kids and comes with over 280 game cards with 12,000 variations for endless re-playability.

Basic Game Overview: In the basic game, a new fantasy picture is revealed (each picture is on a huge 6x4 card). Players choose a Talk Card from their hand which they feel best represents the picture, is the most silly, or drums up the most laughs. One player acts as the Adventure Master, which rotates every turn, reads each Talk Card aloud then chooses a Talk Card he/she likes most. This continues every turn until a player's Talk Card is chosen three times!

Advanced Game Overview:  After choosing your hero (each having a unique game power), you'll draw 5 Dungeon Talk cards (talk cards have funny sayings, quotes, etc on them).

Talk cards are used by you to describe an adventure card (a fantasy scene with some really cool art). Each turn a new adventure card is drawn from the current Act deck of your quest. The acts are The Fellowship, Journey, and Destination.

Each turn a new player acts as the Adventure Master (AM). Players, except the AM, chooses a talk card from their hand and plays it face down.

The AM then draws a random talk card from the talk card deck and shuffles it in with the players' chosen talk cards. He reads aloud each talk card and chooses one he/she feels best describes the picture, is the funniest, most outrageous, drums up the most laughs, and so on.

If a player's card is chosen he gains a level and loot (loot can be in the form of gold coins, equipment,potions, spells, or weapons which can be used to aid yourself or hinder others).

If the random card was chosen, one player is cursed (a random negative effect is played on him). Throughout the game, players can use their special hero power and unique items they've earned to help themselves or hinder other players getting too close to winning!

The game ends when a player reaches glorious level 5! Whomever has accumulated the most gold wins! There's a few more rules but that's the general gist of Dungeon Talk.

name: Contract Whist
description:
Retrieved from http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/67991987

The Advocate, Burnie, Tasmania, Australia, 31 Dec. 1932.

				
				
					CONTRACT WHIST.

No Hands Down.
WEAKNESS SOLVED.

Why a four-handed game of cards such as the various forms of bridge should be played by three persons is one of those mysteries that have never been explained. Probably this is because there is no explanation. It seems absurd that one of the four players should have to stand out of every game.

And if the game is one of skill, as is confidently asserted, its value is much diminished by the exposure of one of the hands.

In whist each player knew only what was in his own hand. He had to use his reason or his imagination to decide what was in the hands of his partner or of his two opponents.

				
				
					Bridge Without the Dummy.

In the various forms of bridge his partner's hand is exposed once the bidding is over. Each player knows two hands, and so much of the real interest of the game is lost.

It is these things that have led to the invention of contract whist, or "bridge without the dummy," as set out by Hubert Phillips in "Contract Whist."

This is distinctly a whist game, since each player plays his own hand. There is no exposure of one hand, as in bridge. It is this, the author claims, which gives the game its special fascination. And, indeed, it is a sensible idea.

On the other hand, the bidding and scoring follow the lines of contract bridge, with changes and simplification.

As there is no recognised organisation to frame the rules of contract whist, the author has done it himself. He does not, however, claim to have invented the game. He says that the idea of bridge without the dummy has existed for years. The rule that only tricks actually contracted for can count towards the game is retained. The things rejected are, "Vulnerability, the bidding of slams, and unnecessarily complicated scoring."

				
				
					The Scoring.

The scoring suggested is:

(1) A game is secured by the first side that scores 10 points. Rubber is the best of three games.

(2) Points count toward game only when scored "below the line." These are points for tricks which the declaring side has contracted to make. Tricks at No Trumps count 4 points each. Tricks at a suit declaration count 3 points each. Tricks made by the declarers, but not contracted for are scored above the line, and count only 2 each. Where a contract has been doubled or redoubled, the value of each trick is doubled or redoubled. Over tricks are 5 each doubled, and 10 redoubled.

(3) Where the contract is defeated the defending side scores [above the line] 10 points for each trick which the declaring side has failed to make. If the contract has been doubled the deficiency score is 20 points; if redoubled 40.

(4) Nothing is scored for honors.

(5) The side winning the rubber receives 50 points.

				
				
					Rubber of 100 Points.

The average rubber is about 100 points in all.
While the score is the same for all suit declarations, the preference in bidding is the same as in bridge--spades, hearts, diamonds, clubs.

Contract whist differs from bridge in that the play cannot be planned by the declarer from the outset.

The author gives many illustrations which suggest that contract whist could be made a most fascinating game.

name: Garbage Pail Kids: Super Snot Shots
description:
Garbage Pail Kids: Super Snot Shots supports 2-4 players and is a dexterity game that involves flicking dice (that represent snot) at a target. Each player chooses one of the four snot-covered Leaky Lindsay cards and a six-sided die of the same color, then takes a position around a target card. The cards in the game are all squares with rounded edges; they feature eleven Garbage Pail kids, all featuring classic Garbage Pail Kids art, everyone from Surf's Up Chuck to Dead Ted to Mark Barf.

You make a draw pile out of the cards and select one to be a target, placing it in the middle of everyone and placing your Leaky Lindsay card two card-lengths away. Once set-up is complete, count down "3, 2, 1, SHOOT!", then flick your die from your Lindsay card towards the target card, trying to aim it so that your die stops on top of it. If only one player gets her die on the target card, she claims it; if two or more dice land on the card, then whoever has the highest number showing on her die wins it; if no one lands on the card, then it's a tie and everyone shoots again!

The game continues until no cards remain, and whoever has the most cards wins.

name: Captoons: The Game of Comic Foreplay and Social Intercourse
description: Captoons is a game for seemingly mature, yet frisky adults, that has been called “the most fun you can have with your clothes on!”  And it’s easy.  Each player simply matches a caption card chosen from their hand to the cartoon in play.  The Card Captain, randomly chosen, then announces what he feels is the funniest pairing.  And that’s where the fun really starts.  In a game featuring 450 captions, 80 cartoons and 36,000 possible pairings!!, the Card Captain’s choice may be about as popular as a fart in a hermetically sealed space suit, leading to rather spirited and hilarious interactions between the players.

name: DC Comics Deck-Building Game: Teen Titans
description:
Teen Titans go! You've played with the old guard. Now play as the youthful up-and-comers. Play as Raven, Beast Boy, Wonder Girl, Red Robin and more. The Teen Titans are all about proving themselves, and with this set you can save your best cards for when you really need them. When you’re ready, unleash everything you’ve got and the results will be spectacular.

The big new focus of DC Comics Deck-Building Game: Teen Titans revolves around Ongoing abilities: Cards that stay in play until you need them. Every time you put an Ongoing card into play, it essentially gives you an extra card to utilize on a future turn. Previously, only Locations and a couple of other cards could ever stay in play. Now every card type at every power level has multiple different cards with Ongoing. Sometimes they help you every turn. But mostly they stay in play until you choose to discard them for their mighty effects. If you can build up several Ongoing cards, unleash as many as you need to take down the Super-Villains!

This set also pays attention to the different card types you have in play. Playing cards from your hand puts cards into play as usual. But with Ongoing cards out there, you often have several card types in play already. Such synergy!

name: Paper Toss
description:
Paper Toss is a fast, fun, new card game where players compete to deliver the most newspapers on their paper route.

Paper Toss can be played by 2 to 6 players in anywhere from 10 to 30 minutes (more players make longer games), and the rules are simple and easy to learn, suitable for ages 5 and up.

The comical art and theme, coupled with the silly, competitive nature of the game make it great for younger children and even the whole family.

Draw cards from the blue "Paper Deck," and take turns trying to toss your newspaper on a new doormat (by playing the "Paper Toss" card), as other players try to throw off your aim with hazards like angry dogs, sidewalk obstacles, and neighborhood kids. If you have the appropriate counter card, you can ignore the distraction.

A simple discard mechanic adds a subtle layer of strategy: choose which cards to hold or discard, keeping your defensive cards, or going on the offense. Wild cards like "Flat Tire!" and "Bully!" help you stick it to your opponent and gain an upper hand.

Once you throw your paper, turn over a card from the green "Toss Deck," to see how good your throw was. With every successful paper toss, you gain a Paper Token. The first player to collect 10 Tokens wins the game! Can you be the first one to toss all your papers?

name: One-Minute War
description:
You and your opponent each command a tiny army of five soldiers. Each round, you and your opponent simultaneously choose one of your soldiers to fight. However, not every soldier is created equal--some are stronger than others, and some have special abilities. Can you anticipate your opponent's move and choose a soldier that will beat his? Will he make the "obvious" choice, or will he pull a bluff...or a double-bluff? Win the war by defeating all of your opponent's soldiers, or having more remaining soldiers when the war is over.

This game requires one card (included in the download) and three hands--one of yours, one belonging to a friend, and another one of yours to hold the card. No tabletop needed.

After 4 turns, the player with more points is the winner...

name: Terraforming Mars
description:
In the 2400s, mankind begins to terraform the planet Mars. Giant corporations, sponsored by the World Government on Earth, initiate huge projects to raise the temperature, the oxygen level, and the ocean coverage until the environment is habitable. In Terraforming Mars, you play one of those corporations and work together in the terraforming process, but compete for getting victory points that are awarded not only for your contribution to the terraforming, but also for advancing human infrastructure throughout the solar system, and doing other commendable things.

The players acquire unique project cards (from over two hundred different ones) by buying them to their hand. The projects (cards) can represent anything from introducing plant life or animals, hurling asteroids at the surface, building cities, to mining the moons of Jupiter and establishing greenhouse gas industries to heat up the atmosphere. The cards can give you immediate bonuses, as well as increasing your production of different resources. Many cards also have requirements and they become playable when the temperature, oxygen, or ocean coverage increases enough. Buying cards is costly, so there is a balance between buying cards (3 megacredits per card) and actually playing them (which can cost anything between 0 to 41 megacredits, depending on the project). Standard Projects are always available to complement your cards.

Your basic income, as well as your basic score, is based on your Terraform Rating (starting at 20), which increases every time you raise one of the three global parameters. However, your income is complemented with your production, and you also get VPs from many other sources.

Each player keeps track of their production and resources on their player boards, and the game uses six types of resources: MegaCredits, Steel, Titanium, Plants, Energy, and Heat. On the game board, you compete for the best places for your city tiles, ocean tiles, and greenery tiles. You also compete for different Milestones and Awards worth many VPs. Each round is called a generation (guess why) and consists of the following phases:

1) Player order shifts clockwise.
2) Research phase: All players buy cards from four privately drawn.
3) Action phase: Players take turns doing 1-2 actions from these options: Playing a card, claiming a Milestone, funding an Award, using a Standard project, converting plant into greenery tiles (and raising oxygen), converting heat into a temperature raise, and using the action of a card in play. The turn continues around the table (sometimes several laps) until all players have passed.
4) Production phase: Players get resources according to their terraform rating and production parameters.

When the three global parameters (temperature, oxygen, ocean) have all reached their goal, the terraforming is complete, and the game ends after that generation. Count your Terraform Rating and other VPs to determine the winning corporation!

Guspira is a funny, quick and suitable board game for all ages, inspired on the world of fire, devils, beasts and everything related to a ‘correfoc’, one of the most gorgeous and spectacular fests of the Catalan culture. Among the game cards there are some characteristic elements of this celebration as ‘Drac’, ‘Víbria’, ‘Guita’, Devils or ‘Tabalers’, without forgetting ‘correfocaires’, brave people who jump and dance under the fire.

The main objective is to win the maximum number of ‘correfocaires’ playing the pyrotechnic cards from the hand. But it is not always as easy as it seems to be, the dice has also its role…

Besides the playful side, Guspira is expected to be a way of promotion for the Catalan culture. The cards show the most characteristic elements of this celebration and they have no text in order to be played anywhere in the world.

name: Stack Tac Toe

name: Butim
description:
Butim (Spoil, in portuguese) is a competitive pirate game where players compete with each other for the best equipment, pieces of maps and hidden treasures. It's a party game of luck and strategy where you will cheat, steal, bother and disrupt the lives of your opponents. There is no honor among pirates! There is no elimination, that is, who enters the game stays until the end and everyone has a chance to win.

Butim is a card game that tells the story of the Bloody Islands Archipelago. These islands were used by generations of pirates to hide the biggest secrets that sailed the 7 seas. But all the pirates who buried their treasures there, also armed the most terrible traps so that these treasures stay properly protected. It was a beautiful and deadly place. However, as every story has an end, on a beautiful day a mysterious maelstrom opened near the islands and is leaching the islands with all this wealth to the bottom of the ocean. The objective of the game is to remove as many treasures as possible from these islands before they vanish forever. The player who has more wealth at the end of the game is declared the winner.

During the game you draw resources and cards, dig the islands (draw island cards) looking for maps and treasures and play special cards. At the end of a round cards are removed from the islands to the maelstrom. The game ends when a number of islands were totally removed.

name: Battle of Golems: The Algorithmic Card Game
description:
The first tabletop game that allows you to simply and easily learn programming and robotics without a computer (with conditions, loop, logic, subprogram etc), and to enjoy discovering exciting strategies! For 2 to 4 players, aged 8 years and older (but played from 5-6+ ages). Training of logic, memory, team interaction - all this in a simple, but deep in content, a board game. Play at home with children, in the company, at school and use it in STEM additional education.

Welcome to the Battle of Golems! Algorythmus archmage by Cybertania’s king’s order created Golems - clay robot warriors using coal as fuel. Due to the magic crystal in its head Golem can follow commands and perform short series of them called Programs. King also ordered to build a special field, which would be used for battles between warrior programmers and their Golems. You will take part in the tournament and prove that you’re the best robot engineer of Cybertania.

In 10 rounds each player set up the Program for his Robot-Golem from Action cards and executes it. The Damage tokens and Cards of Fortune will show you how many rounds and lives remain before the victory and whether you can apply Cycles, Conditions or other Bonuses when writing the Program.

You and your opponents in each round usually have four programming slots (depending on the type of Golem), so you need to take care of a short but effective algorithm. You can use both ready-made scenarios (more then 10+ including in Scenario book) and create your own rules, fields, and actions!

Equipment:

• 5 two-sided (summer-winter) board pieces: (4 3x3 sizes and 1 4x4 size) (Print&Play includes only 1 4x4 size)
• 4 Golems figures 
• 6 two-sided golem cards
• 76 action cards
• 12 Damage tokens for 4 players

name: Colis Party
description:
Try to deliver your packet as soon as possible to mailman Johnny.

Each player chooses a card (indicating means of mail delivery transport) from his hand and passes it face down to his right of left neighbour (direction is given by Johnny the mailman). When all players have a hidden card in front of them, they turn the cards at the same time. The card in front of each player indicates which combination he/she should make. They have to see how much identical cards are revealed by other players, and how much identical cards they have on their hand. This indicates on which number they have to tap (2, 3 of 4) as soon as possible. If they see 5 identical cards, they shout "timbré" (=stamped).

Players who tapped rightfully at 2, 3 of 4 can take pieces of a packet. They get 2 cards (showing parts of a postpacket) from the deck, keep 1 and discard the other one. The player who tapped the 3 can make, after choising from two cards, an additional move: steal a card from an other player. The player who could tap the 4 can choose a piece (out of two cards), steal another and gets the mailman. He/she also decides in which direction the cards are given in the next round. The players who tapped wrongfully, must discard a card from their packet.

If a player can show 5 identical cards, he shouts "timbré". He'll be the only one playing this round. He takes 5 cards from the deck, keep 1 and discard 4, steals a card and takes the mailman. The other players must discard a piece (card) of their packet.

For the next round players take the card in front of them in their hands and play a hidden card to the right or left player, as isntructed by the (new) mailman.

As soon as a player had his 6 pieces (cards) of the packet AND the mailman, he/she wins!

name: Quick Backgammon
description:
Quick Backgammon is two games in one box. The first game is QuickGammon, a scaled down variant of backgammon that has fewer pieces and fewer points on the board, and uses d4 dice. Quickgammon is an introductory game to teach children and beginners the principles of backgammon.

Also included in the box is a standard backgammon board, and the game includes d6 dice and enough pieces to play the standard game.

[User summary from game box and rules.]

name: The Zombie
description:
The Zombie is a micro-game of cunning and bluff. Taking the concept of the famous Werewolf game (Mafia), the game features some child trying to escape a zombie invasion.

Players receive a card at the start of the round and they try to eliminate the "right" player depending on their role. Players will vote each round trying to "survive" as long as possible.

The Zombie is a fast game (about 5 minutes) of bluffing and deception, it’s the perfect «filler» for any group. The game contains only 4 cards and it take less than 1 minute to explain. The game is easy to transport, does not take space and can be played almost anywhere; in queues, in a bar, in the car, during a break.

name: Gang Up!
description:
Gang Up! is casual card game where you compete to become the ultimate crime lord! Recruit legendary gang members and commit crazy daring crimes. Use criminal influences and team up with other players to get ahead. And when they least expect it, backstab them to win the game!

What's so good about Gang Up!?

Well...!


    Constantly choose between helping or backstabbing friends!

    And it's easy to learn & quick to play!


Version 1: Kickstarter edition (english, 2015)
verion  2; published by HOT Games (english, 2016) & Czacha Games (polish, 2017)

description:

    Play one ability per turn, simultaneously. You have access to all of your abilities every turn.
    Gain and spend "focus" using your ability cards.
    Reveal rune cards for bonus effects on the ability you play.
    Play a "level up" ability to add a wild card to your rune deck, giving you better odds on bonus effects for the rest of the game.
    Move and attack using your ability cards.
    Make meaningful choices about how to spend focus such as:
        Tactical Movement
        Fast, high damage attacks
        Level up for a late game strategy

name: Big Time Hoops
description:
Big Time Hoops is a fast-playing, card-based simulation of professional basketball for two players. To recreate the flow of the game and remove "housekeeping" altogether, the game eschews individual cards for basketball players and focuses exclusively on the major action elements of the sport.

In general, you'll hold a hand of three cards, most of which will be offensive in nature. You'll play one of them, choosing to pass the ball or drive to the basket; each card will result in a shot attempt with a varying degree of success. Then you'll roll a die. If the shot fails, the card states which side gets the rebound. (Yes, three-point shots are in the game.)

Your opponent can play a defensive card, and when used wisely he'll steal a pass, block a shot or foul your shooter.

Simulating realistic scoring requires a delicate balance in a sport where each team averages 100 points per game. Rest assured that you'll find it here, as the number of two-pointers, three-pointers and foul shots will be very close to their actual real-life averages each and every game.

Playable in an hour, Big Time Hoops will provide all the fun and excitement of real pro basketball -- without the high ticket prices!

name: Jo & Jack
description:
Welcome to Grim City / town of quirky characters
It is very simple: Collect as many points in a same color, then you are well regarded.
Optimize your hand as soon as possible. If a player closes his hand, the fun is over!
Joker and Doubler help you while foreign Hi-Jacks poach in their own ranks and make seemingly safe points to nothing.
Turbulent, exciting and fast it goes on here - can you keep up?

excerpt of the official rules: 
Each player receives 3 cards on hand. 3 more cards are placed side by side for all players on the table.
The remaining cards form a draw pile deck. The players try to collect as many points in a same suit (red, green or black).
During the game the player's hand can gradually optimized with the table cards. In each round, each player has exactly one of several possible actions. 
Note: During the game each player always has 3 cards in hand and on the table are always 3 cards open. 
The game is played over several singles matches. The player with the lowest result at the end of a single match, loses a credit (chip card is rotated accordingly). 
The player is completely out of the game if he can not bring this stake. 
Note: If several players at the same time have the lowest result (tied), each of these players lose a credit.


            
        
    


Willkommen in Grim-City / die Stadt der skurrilen Persönlichkeiten
Es ist ganz einfach: Sammle möglichst viele Punkte in einer gleichen Farbe, dann bist Du gut angesehen.
Optimiere Dein Blatt so schnell es geht. Macht ein Spieler dicht, ist Schluss mit lustig!
Joker und Doppler helfen Dir, während fremde Hi-Jacks in den eigenen Reihen wildern und sicher geglaubte Punkte zunichte machen.
Turbulent, spannend und schnell geht es hier zu - kannst Du mithalten?

Auszug des offiziellen Regelwerks:
Jeder Spieler erhält 3 Karten auf die Hand. 3 weitere Karten werden für alle Spieler offen nebeneinander auf den Tisch ausgelegt. 
Die restlichen Karten bilden einen verdeckten Nachziehstapel. 
Die Spieler versuchen möglichst viele Punkte in einer gleichen Spielfarbe zu sammeln (rot, grün oder schwarz). 
Mit den ausliegenden Karten werden die eigenen Handkarten nach Bedarf im laufenden Spiel nach und nach
optimiert. Pro Runde hat jeder Spieler immer genau eine von mehreren möglichen Aktionen zur Verfügung.
Hinweis: Während des Spiels hat jeder Spieler immer 3 Karten auf der Hand und auf dem
Tisch liegen immer 3 Karten offen aus.
Das Spiel wird über mehrere Einzelspiele gespielt. Der Spieler mit dem schlechtesten Ergebnis eines
Einzelspiels verliert einen Credit (Chipkarte wird entsprechend gedreht). Der Spieler ist ganz aus dem
Spiel, wenn er diesen Einsatz nicht mehr bringen kann. 
Hinweis: Haben mehrere Spieler zeitgleich das
schlechteste Ergebnis (punktgleich), verliert jeder dieser Spieler einen Credit.

name: Almirante
description:
English description:

"As almirantes - Portuguese for admirals - in command of both a merchant and a war navy, 2 to 6 players build and navigate their fleets in order to dominate the geostrategic center of the ocean. In this exciting strategy game, however, one must call for divine help as conquering the ocean is nothing compared to holding it…"

Each almirante has the goal of dominating the ocean, that is, conquering and holding the field in the center of both ocean and board. For that, he or she builds and sails a fleet of both fishing boats and war galleons, by cleverly using the resources received in the beginning of each play: winds and coins. In addition, each almirante has three opportunities to use a god card.

Each play starts by receiving 6 winds and a variable amount of coins. Winds allow you to move your vessels: you need 1 wind to sail a fishing boat to another field, and 2 winds to do the same with a heavier galleon. Coins allow you to build new vessels: fishing boats cost you 2 coins, while galleons cost you 8 coins. You can trade these two resources, if you are willing to pay a conversion fee.

You then move your vessels. Sail your fishing boats to the shoal fields to fish and earn coins on your next turns (2 coins per each of the 6 shoals players compete for). Sail your galleons to meet opponent vessels in order to fight battles, or go for the center to conquer it. Battles are always won by the almirante with the most galleons on that field. Some defeated vessels are sunk and some of them may flee.

If the time is right, call upon the gods! Each almirante chose 3 god cards from equal pools of 8 before the game started, kept them secret and can now play each of them once - but only once. Play Aeolus and he will grant you extra winds, or maybe play Ares and he will sink an opponent's vessel...

Your play is now over. Are your galleons dominating the center of the ocean? Good, then slide one point along the scoreboard. Do this 4 times (in a game with 3-5 players) to win. But look out, the other almirantes are now sourrunding you and will want to join efforts to stop your countdown toward victory. Will they get you?


Portuguese Description:

Enquanto almirantes, no comando tanto de uma marinha mercante como de uma de guerra, 2 a 6 jogadores constroem e dirigem as suas frotas para dominar o centro geoestratégico do oceano. Neste entusiasmante jogo de estratégia, porém, têm de apelar a uma ajuda divina já que conquistar o oceano não é nada comparado a mantê-lo...

name: Franky Reloaded
description:
Franky is back!
In a secret laboratory, the players try to assemble as many Frankies as possible and then activate them with lightning flashes. Only energy charged Frankies can score in the game.
Not every Franky is the same, the risky ’small’ red Frankies can win the most victory points ..

excerpt of the official rules: 
The object of the game is to win 12 victory points or more. The highest number of victory points wins the game. In case of a tie of victory points a flash-duel (between the affected players) takes place in a special round. Note: Victory point is a funny reference to the fictional character Victor Frankenstein.
How to play: Each game round the player has a regular dice turn with multiple number of rolls. After each roll, any number of dice can be laid aside, but at least 1 die is always required! Dice which are laid aside cannot be re-rolled in this round. At the end of the regular dice turn (all dice are laid aside) the result is evaluated. A lightning flash symbolizes a victory point, but only if the player can assemble a complete Franky in a same color (2 other dice in green or according violet). A green or violet Franky is always assembled with a head and a body.
Note: If you want to achieve a regular victory point this way, always 3 dice are necessary.
Red Frankies: After the player has completed his regular dice turn (all dice are laid aside), all red Frankies are rolled once again. Here the player has gained special chances with these dice. A red Franky can immediately achieve victory points if he shows a flash after the rolling (the red Franky has been activated). Here no assembly with other dice is required because the red Franky is already complete (custom-made). Displays the die (after the roll) again a red Franky, he will be re-rolled again, all other symbols do not help anymore.
Note: If the player wins victory points this way, only 1 single die is necessary. Depending on how many red Frankies the player has laid aside, a lot of victory points can be earned.

excerpt of the official rules Blue Eyes (included first expansion): 
The player can try to score victory points as usual. If he plays a total of victory points that is similar with the number the blue spot die shows, the victory points can be doubled. Note: The player can decide to devaluate any number of victory points to fulfill the spot die (only
complete activated Frankies can be devaluated).


            
        
    


Franky ist zurück!
Im geheimen Labor versuchen die Spieler möglichst viele Frankys zusammenzubauen und diese dann mit Energieblitzen zu aktivieren. Nur energiegeladene Frankys können im Spiel punkten. 
Nicht jeder Franky ist gleich, die riskanten „kleinen” roten Frankys können die meisten Siegpunkte erspielen ..

Auszug des offiziellen Regelwerks:
Spielziel sind 12 Siegpunkte oder mehr. Die höchste Anzahl an Siegpunkten gewinnt das Spiel. Bei Gleichstand von Siegpunkten wird ein Blitz-Duell in einer Sonderrunde ausgetragen.
Spielüberblick: Pro Spielrunde hat der Spieler einen regulären Würfeldurchgang mit mehreren Würfen. Nach jedem Wurf können beliebig viele Würfel rausgelegt werden, mindestens 1 Würfel ist aber immer Pflicht! Rausgelegte Würfel können in dieser Runde nicht wieder neu mitgewürfelt werden. Erst am Ende des regulären Würfeldurchgangs (alle Würfel sind rausgelegt) wird das Ergebnis gewertet. Ein Energieblitz bedeutet einen Siegpunkt, welcher aber erst durch den Zusammenbau von einem Franky in einer gleichen Farbe (2 andere Würfel in grün oder entsprechend violett) gewertet werden kann. Ein grüner oder violetter Franky wird immer zusammengebaut mit Kopf und Rumpf.
Hinweis: Soll auf diese Weise ein regulärer Siegpunkt erzielt werden, sind dafür immer 3 Würfel notwendig.
Rote Frankys: Nachdem der Spieler seinen regulären Würfeldurchgang abgeschlossen hat (alle Würfel sind rausgelegt), werden alle roten Frankys einmalig erneut gewürfelt; der Spieler hat sich bei diesen Würfeln Sonderchancen erspielt. Ein roter Franky kann sofort Siegpunkte erzielen, wenn er jetzt nach dem würfeln einen Energieblitz zeigt (der rote Franky wurde aktiviert). Hier ist kein Zusammenbau mit anderen Würfeln erforderlich, da die roten Frankys schon komplett sind (Sonderanfertigungen). Zeigt der Würfel (nach dem würfeln) erneut einen roten Franky, wird dieser als Wiederholung erneut gewürfelt, alle anderen Symbole bringen nichts mehr.
Hinweis: Sollen also so Siegpunkte erspielt werden, ist hierfür nur 1 einziger Würfel notwendig. Auf diese Weise können beliebig viele Siegpunkte erspielt werden, je nachdem wie viele rote Frankys der Spieler rausgelegt hat.

Auszug des offiziellen Regelwerks Blue Eyes (enthaltene erste Erweiterung):
Der Spieler kann ganz normal auf Siegpunkte spielen. Schafft er es jedoch genau so viele Siegpunkte zu erspielen, wie der Augenwürfel zeigt, können die Siegpunkte verdoppelt werden.
Hinweis: Der Spieler kann sich entscheiden Siegpunkte verfallen zu lassen (nur komplett aktivierte Frankys können verfallen), damit der Augenwürfel erfüllt werden kann.

name: Opération Commando: Pegasus Bridge
description:
(Version française ci-dessous.)

In 1944, during the night of 5th to 6th June, paratroopers of the British 6th Airborne achieved three heroic missions that made possible the D-Day Normandy Landings on the East sector (Gold, Juno and Sword beaches). 
In Operation Commando - Pegasus Bridge, one player leads the English commandos, while his opponent is in charge of the defending German troops.

Each turn, on a different battlefield (each ground having specific characteristics), players draw cards (each player has his own deck), can play events, and then an assault begins. The German plays a unit; the English answers with a unit, that must have a Combat value equal or higher than the German unit's, or reach it thanks to boosts. If it does, the German can boost his unit, then the English, and so on until a player stops. A unit's combat value can be raised by combat action cards and tokens (one side +1 Combat, one blank side) taken from the player's tokens reserve and flipped.
If the English's unit is destroyed, he loses one of his 3 Manpower Points (MP) but moves to the next ground (the assault ends, as does the turn on this ground). If the German's unit is destroyed, he can play another one (depending on the ground's size) and the assault goes on. If the English destroys all enemy units present on the ground, he wins the assault and progresses without losing a MP.

Players also have a pool of special cards, the powerful "heroic" cards, from which they secretely choose one card to add to their hand each two turns. Since heroic cards have potent effects and can't be countered, choosing them well depending on the situation of the game is strategically very important. These cards feature actual historical officers and events.

The game contains three scenarios, each of which corresponding to one of the three missions that the English commandos had to fulfill this night: the taking of the bridge of Bénouville ("Pegasus Bridge") to allow the landed troops to progress deeper inside the land; the assault on the Merville Gun Battery, a fortified area threatening the Landind beaches with long distance cannons; and the bombing of the bridges on the Dives river to prevent the tanks of the 21th Panzer Division from reinforcing the German troops. Each scenario has its own pool of cards (including heroic cards) and different gameplays.

To win, the English must fulfill his objective (which depends of the scenario), by winning the assault on one or more objective grounds. To win, the German has to prevent the English to reach his goal, generally by bringing his Manpower Points to zero or, in the Dives scenario, by preventing him to destroy two bridges out of four.

The three scenarios can be played in campaign mode (one after the other) to recreate the historic night. Depending on his results, the English gets more or less campaign points, and when the three scenarios have been played, his total score indicates if the D-Day Landing will be possible or not.

The 120 artworks illustrating the cards are realistic and faithful to historical documents (uniforms, weapons, locations...)

---

En 1944, pendant la nuit du 5 au 6 juin, les parachutistes de la 6e Division Aéroportée Britannique ("6th Airborne") accomplirent trois missions héroïques qui permirent au Débarquement d'avoir lieu sur le secteur est (plages Gold, Juno et Sword).
Dans **Opération Commando - Pegasus Bridge**, l'un des joueurs dirige les commandos anglais, et son adversaire les troupes allemandes.

À chaque tour, sur un champ de bataille différent (chaque terrain possédant des caractéristiques spécifiques), les joueurs piochent des cartes (chacun a sa propre pioche), peuvent jouer des événements, puis un assaut commence. L'Allemand joue une unité ; l'Anglais répond par une unité, qui doit avoir une valeur de combat égale ou supérieure à celle de l'unité allemande, ou l'atteindre grâce à des bonus. Si c'est le cas, l'Allemand peut renforcer son unité, puis l'Anglais peut faire de même, et ainsi de suite jusqu'à ce qu'un joueur renonce. La valeur de combat d'une unité peut être augmentée grâce à des actions de combat et des jetons (avec une face +1 et une face sans bonus) pris dans la réserve du joueur et jetés en l'air comme un pile ou face.
Si l'unité de l'Anglais est détruite, il perd l'un de ses 3 Points d'Effectifs (PE) mais avance jusqu'au prochain terrain (l'assaut se termine, de même que le tour sur ce terrain). Si c'est l'unité de l'Allemand qui est détruite, ce dernier peut en jouer une autre (selon la taille du terrain) et l'assaut se poursuit. Si l'Anglais élimine toutes les unités ennemies présentes, il remporte l'assaut et progresse sans perdre de PE.

Les joueurs disposent également d'une réserve de cartes spéciales, les puissantes cartes "héroïques", réserve dans laquelle ils choisissent secrètement une carte qu'ils ajoutent à leur main tous les deux tours. Les cartes héroïques ayant des effets puissants et ne pouvant être annulées, bien les choisir en fonction du déroulement de la partie est stratégiquement très important. Ces cartes représentent des officiers ayant réellement pris part aux opérations et des événements s'étant effectivement produits.

Le jeu propose trois scénarios, chacun d'eux correspondant à l'une des trois missions que les commandos anglais devaient accomplir cette nuit-là : la prise du pont de Bénouville ("Pegasus Bridge") pour permettre aux troupes débarquées de progresser à l'intérieur des terres ; l'assaut sur la batterie de Merville, une zone fortifiée menaçant les plages du Débarquement avec des canons à longue portée ; et la destruction des ponts sur la rivière Dives pour empêcher les blindés de la 21e Panzer Division de venir renforcer les troupes allemandes. Chaque scénario possède ses propres cartes (dont les cartes héroïques) et des mécaniques de jeu différentes.

Pour gagner, l'Anglais doit remplir sa mission (qui dépend du scénario), en remportant l'assaut sur un ou plusieurs terrains objectifs. Pour gagner, l'Allemand doit empêcher l'Anglais d'atteindre son but, généralement en lui faisant perdre tous ses Points d'Effectifs, ou, dans le scénario de la Dives, en l'empêchant de détruire deux des quatre ponts.

Les trois scénarios peuvent être joués à la suite, en mode "campagne", pour recréer cette nuit historique. En fonction de ses résultats, l'Anglais obtient plus ou moins de points de campagne, et quand les trois scénarios ont été joués, son score total indique si le Débarquement sur les plages de Gold, Juno et Sword pourra avoir lieu ou non.

Les 120 illustrations de cartes sont réalistes et fidèles aux documents historiques (uniformes, armes, lieux...)

name: Flat Cube
description:
Flat Cube is a solo card game consisting of six cards with a picture of half a coloured cube on each side, which will form a whole cube when placed next to the correct side of another card.

The player shuffles the cards then places them face up in a row. The aim of the game is to make all the cards line up with matching cubes (except for the two on either end, which will only match on one side).

In order to do this, the player must pull two (and only two) side-by-side cards out from the row and move them to an available slot — either on one end or in a space created by moving two previous cards. Continue doing this until the objective is complete, leaving no spaces and moving only two cards at any one time.

name: Song of Drums and Tomahawks
description:
Do you dare enter into the dark woodlands of early America?

The boom of a flintlock musket, a cloud of acrid black powder, and the drumming of feet as they rush towards the fallen foe. A knife is unsheathed, and with a few quick movements, the enemy’s bloody scalp is ripped free. Warfare in the Eastern Woodlands of America was one of raids, ambushes and sudden violent encounters. These are the skirmishes that Song of Drums and Tomahawks seeks to recreate. The French & Indian War is the most well-known conflict of this period, but these rules cover from the time of the European arrival until the mid-1800s. Players will generally control less than a dozen figures in multiplayer games, perhaps more in one-on-one contests. The fast-paced play, the tense decision making using simple, easy-to-learn rules, will lead to many fun and gripping games.

name: Bestialwars
description:
Bestialwars is a table-top fantasy miniature war game in heroic scale of 10mm {12mm real}, set in the lands of Zaneoss, continent of the flat world of Dabbath.

Bestial Wars is a stubborn game, carrying on the great tradition of the 80’s and 90’s, all miniatures are hand sculpted and casted using lead free metal.

...we just can’t help but love things that weigh !!!

Bestial Wars uses a 12mm scale for all its models, from troops to creatures. Thanks to the small size of the models, Bestial Wars battles are going to feel and look epic; furthermore, the limited number of bases in which miniatures are arranged will allow for fast and smooth deployment and movement. 
This structure makes the grand battles of Bestial Wars playable with the ease of a skirmish game!

Quickly bring the farmer and animals of your color into safety. Throw the dice and see how many places you can move them. Make use of the secret escape or hide in the toilet to escape the danger. Quickly run ... before it's too late!

name: Duel of Legends
description:
Duel of Legends is a combat card game where the players take on the roles of Legends of different class types. They use Weapon and Defense items, along with Spell cards to try and defeat their opponents and be the last legend standing.

Average play time per Duel is 5-10 mins (2 players). Turns are fast but every choice has game changing effects. Easy Learning Curve: Most players feel comfortable with the game after 1 or 2 Duels. The game mechanics are simple, it’s the choices you make that separate the beginners from the veterans.

Over 1200 Class:Equipment Combinations, over 1.3 million starting Combinations. (with spells) Up to 4 players: Adding more players changes the dynamic of the game dramatically. Deciding who to attack and when is a key factor. In the end there can be only one, so allies don’t stay allies long.

name: The2101Game
description:
The 21st Century's Explosive New Card Game! Move over Poker, there's a new card game in town! The2101Game! It's an exciting new card game that combines skill and luck with a unique twist to provide the ultimate card gaming experience. The2101Game is a very easy game to learn, and it can be played with as many as 11 players. The pot grows with rapid speed, giving every player an opportunity to win BIG! So if you're feeling lucky get your family, friends, and fellow gamers together and start playing The2101Game. The2101Game caters to people of all different gaming backgrounds. From the avid gamers to non-gamers alike, they all agree that The2101Game is one of the simplest yet most complex games that they have ever played. People who are typically and instantly drawn to this game are people who play poker, spades, rummy, Phase 10, and Uno although just having a general knowledge of cards is all you need to play The2101Game.

The2101Game is played with two decks of cards minus a 2 of diamonds, a 10 of clubs, and an Ace of spades.

To start play everyone is dealt 3 sets of cards which are 3 pocket cards (these cards go in your hand and are for your eyes only!), 3 face up cards, and 3 face down cards (which go over above the face up cards). The object of the game is to be the first player to get rid of all 9 of your cards by first playing all of your pocket cards, then all of your face up cards, then finally all of your face down cards. All you have to do is match or beat the card on the pile and if you can't, you pick up the entire pile and must play them all before you play any new cards unless you have  "2101 cards", also referred to as wild cards. There are 3 "2101 cards" which are the 2, 10, and Ace. The 10 is the highest of the 3 cards. When played, the 10 clears the pile and also gives the player another turn. The Ace is the second highest "2101 card". It has no special powers but is just considered high. The lowest "2101 card" is the 2. When played the 2, also referred to as the "any card", starts the pile back low. It can be played on any card and any card can be played on top of it. You can only play your face up cards once you have no pocket cards left and you can only play your face down cards when you have no face up or pocket cards. Pocket cards must be played one at a time unless you have multiples. Multiple cards of the same value can be played together but is not mandatory and suits do not matter. Face Up cards must be played the same way but if you can not beat the card on the pile with one of your face up cards you must pocket that card that you were unable to play along with the entire pile. Face down cards are also played one at a time but once you touch a face down card that is the card you must use. If you can not beat the card on the pile with the chosen face down card you must pocket that card along with the entire pile.

The betting element is what makes the game more interesting. There are 4 betting stages. First the table bet (this is a predetermined amount to get cards (similar to an ante). Second bet is the pocket bet. This bet is made after the cards are dealt but before any cards are played and is initiated by the person with the highest set of face up cards. The "2101 cards" are what is typically looked for when determining who has the highest set of face up cards.  The third bet is the face up bet. The face up bet is initiated by the first player to get to their face up cards without having any pocket cards. The fourth bet is the face down bet. The face down bet is initiated by the first person to get to their face down cards without having any face up or pocket cards. When a bet is initiated, starting to the left of the initiator, players must match the bet to continue in the round. Players also have the option to raise when their turn comes around. If a player does not want to make the bet they must fold their hand and forfeit any already wagered chips.


    Note - once a player puts their bet on the table it can no longer be removed even if the player changes their mind and decides to fold. Betting in turn can significantly reduce the chances of this happening.



    Note - When 4 cards of the same value are played on to the pile it constitutes a clear as a 10 would and also gives the player who played the fourth consecutive card another turn.

name: Flagship Armada
description:
4X Space boardgame revolving around assymetrical factions vying for control of the galaxy.

Each player plays a Faction and is set to a home system.

In this system, he needs to expand his fleet and colonies, so more resources are added to his growing empire.

At his side, each player has a powerful starship called Flagship. This ship research new modules, tactics and technologies.

But beware, other players are doing the same!

Struggle to survive against several threats like Pirates, Transdimensional invaders and opposite factions.

In the end, only one can achieve victory!

name: Hver stal kökunni úr krúsinni?

Hver stal kökunni úr krúsinni? or Who stole the cookie from the cookie jar? is a card game inspired by the children's clap-song.
The goal is to find the vicious cookie thief!

If you happen to be the cookie thief your self you need to eliminate all other players or pass the empty jar to someone else!
The game is played in rounds and points given to players, minus point for being caught with the empty jar, plus point for having the best cake at the end of the game.

The game is illustrated with Icelandic Christmas cookies and cakes.

name: Pot Farm: The Board Game
description:
Your Uncle Floyd has given you and a few of your buds land to grow some recreational crops.

Inspired by the Facebook cult underground hit, Pot Farm: The Board Game is a 2-4 player competitive farming game where farmers plant high risk/high reward plants while protecting themselves from the Ranger deck. Higher payout crops need higher protection or else the Ranger might come to seize them! Using successfully harvested weed, farmers can buy unique items from a rotating Store to enhance their farms in strategic ways. The game ends when the seed bag is empty. The highest valued farm becomes the ultimate Pot Farm!

Players draw from the included Hemp bag and place crop tokens on their farm placards. Just planting on your farm doesn't guarantee the crops safety from Ranger Dick and competing farmers! Successfully harvesting plant tokens to your stash allows players to afford wacky contraptions and buildings from the rotating store deck to place on their farms for awesome combos and boosts to their production.

name: Twisted Kicks
description:
Help your team guess the twisted words by describing and acting them out! The humor of Cards Against Humanity meets the style of Taboo.

How to play:

1. Split your group into two teams. One player starts first.
2. On your turn, draw a rule card. This rule applies to you during your turn. 
3. Then, draw a twisted card. Get your team members to guess the word on your card. Describe it. Act it out. Just don’t read out the restricted words in the middle of the card. 
4. If your team guesses the word, your team keeps that card. Keep drawing twisted cards until your 60-second turn ends. Then, it’s the other team’s turn.
5. Keep playing until everyone has a turn. The team that has the most cards at the end wins.

name: SpeakEasy a Bold Pub Game!
description:
SpeakEasy is a game where players complete social missions. Most missions involve meeting people and making new friends. Others involve competing against your friends in outrageous challenges! Missions are printed on reusable coasters, which fit right in at your local bar, cocktail party, or picnic!

HOW DO I PLAY?
SpeakEasy is so simple to play, even an inebriate could learn! Here are the rules:

1. Draw a coaster. Read the mission out loud to the group.
2. Assign the mission to another player. 
3. That player has 3 minutes to complete the mission.
4. If they succeed, they win the coaster. If they fail (or refuse!), you win it. 
5. The first player to collect 5 coasters wins!

SAMPLE MISSIONS
SpeakEasy has over 25 missions. Each one is designed to stretch your social circle, and introduce you to new people! Here are some samples:

Comic Relief 
"Target player must make a stranger laugh!"

Getting Fresh
"Choose two players. The first one to return with a piece of gum wins this coaster."

Playing with Matches
"Target player must introduce themselves to a stranger of your choice!"

name: Fire Department
description:

Turn the spinner: a '3' allows to enter the board. Step forward according spinner; ending on an orange marked space move 3 additonal steps forward;
ending on a white marked space detour over the red route 
Note:
Likely published 1930s

name: Come About
description:
In Come About players are maritime merchant traders in command of a fleet of trading ships navigating along many perilous trade routes. The player with the most ships along the most  number of trade routes is declared “Nauclerokubernetes”, the Greek word for merchant-master.

Materials
64 double sided tiles, two sets of 32 tiles in two colors Red and Green.
A way of keeping score.

Play
Come About is played on a board-less playing surface.

Two players Red and Green have each two sets of 16 double sided tiles in their chosen color.

Red starts by placing a tile either side up onto the table.
 Players then take turns placing a tile alongside another existing tile, connecting trade routes ( the dotted lines) across tile edges.

The game ends when all the tiles have been played.

A trade route is a continuous dotted line or loop containing 3 or more ships in either players color.

The player having the majority of ships in his color on a trade route scores 1 point for each of his ships. If a trade route has an equal number of ships in both colors, then neither player scores along that trade route.

The player with the highest score wins.

name: Character Quest: Heroes The Card Game – Game Pack #1: King's Guard
description:
Goblins are pillaging the countryside. Heroes are lining up to gain loot and fame. Which player will have the most successful hero tavern in the land?

In Character Quest: Heroes The Card Game – Game Pack #1 – King's Guard, up to four players take turns collecting heroes and sending them out to gain victory points for your tavern. From the mighty Paladins and Wardens of the King's Guard Tavern to the powerful Great Wolves and Berserkers of the Savage Beasts Tavern, each player will try to create a powerful combo of heroes to defeat even the toughest locations.

Only one deck is needed for up to four players; extra decks can be used separately by each player or shuffled together for everyone to share. Despite the "TCG" in the title, the components of the items in the game are fixed, not randomly distributed.

name: Bill Shakespeare Is Dead
description:
Bill Shakespeare is Dead is a highbrow/lowbrow party game for at least 5 players. There are variants for 3 and 4 players.

Transport yourself back to 17th century England. Ah, the good old days. The smell of feces and dead hobos in the street. The sight of unwashed masses and the complete lack of hygiene. Isn’t it lovely? You and your fellow players are members of the King’s Men, and you make your living saying pretty words to hundreds of filthy people. Better than digging ditches, right? Well tonight is supposed to be the opening night of a brand new play. The crowds are already gathered in the Globe Theatre, and the only thing missing is your star playwright, Bill Shakespeare. As it turns out, Bill had a little too much pickled herring and a lot too much wine and is as dead as disco. Now, armed with nothing but patches of the new script and (sometimes obscene) scribbles in the margins, you all need to put on a show. Good luck!

In Bill Shakespeare is Dead, one of Shakespeare’s famous plays is split into five short acts. During each act, one person acts as the Stage Manager, and two people are randomly chosen to act out the scene. As they go through the script, the rest of the players will have to fill in missing nouns and verbs randomly drawn from the deck and helpfully shouted when there is a blank part in the script. The Stage Manager chooses which nouns and verbs go where. At the end, you can tally your points and declare a winner, if that’s your sort of thing.

name: Star Wars: The Deckbuilder
description: A first in utilizing the franchise and its concepts of "Light vs. Dark" in designing a deckbuilder. Players start with a deck loaded with emotion; light and dark; and set on a path to recruit heroes of the light side and villains of the dark side in a quest to speed to planets across the galaxy and complete missions for the glory of the rebellion (or the empire?). Decide the fate of the galaxy in Star Wars: The Deckbuilder.  For 2-5 players, apx. 20 mins. per player.  First game in a newly designed Deck builder model.

name: My Life as a Card Game
description: Collectible card game depicting players' lives!  Build your deck around your life's greatest accomplishments, your goals, dreams and failures.  Be the most successful as you tell your life's story in duel and multi-player formats!  The game "ends" when one players life (deck) runs out!  Count up your accomplishments and the winner is the one who's lived the "best" life.  Variable scoring options entice ccg hobbists to build different deck types and play themselves...or as the person they'd like to be!

name: Grifters
description:
Grifters is a hand-building game that has all the fun of deck-building games, without the deck. Set in the Dystopian Universe, players take on the role of powerful crime bosses, building their criminal organizations by carefully recruiting new operatives with specialized skills and directing their team’s nefarious deeds. All of your specialists are either in play or in your hand, ready to be used as you command. This unique hand-building mechanism gives you total control of your strategy.

Grifters is all about stealing as much money as you can from the corrupt government, malicious corporations, and your rival players. Each player starts the game with a hand of six Specialist cards, each with unique abilities. Your objective is to use this team of six Specialists to recruit more criminals, complete jobs, steal from the government coffers and swindle your opponents.

Each specialist has a special ability and skill. On your turn you can play a single specialist to perform their ability, or you can play a team of specialists to use their combined skills to complete a job. This means every specialist is a valuable asset to your criminal enterprise, earning immediate benefit through abilities and valuable end-game bonuses by completing jobs against the same target. And because all the cards in your deck are always available, you decide how to maximize your play.

Grifters uses a unique card "cooldown" system to control the use of your cards. On your turn, you play one or more specialist cards into the first "Night" of your hideout. If you already have a specialist card, or a team of specialist cards, in night one those cards advance to night two and push other cards through your hideout.

When a card is pushed out of the third night of your hideout it enters the refresh area. Any cards in your refresh area will return to your hand at the end of your turn.

The game ends when the coffers run out of money, there are no more jobs left to complete, or if there are no more specialists cards left for recruiting. End game bonuses are calculated for completing multiple jobs against the same target.  The player with the most money wins.

---

The Grifters (1st Ed) was first released via Kickstarter with the following backer exclusives:

Upgraded player tableaus - A thick chipboard tableau with linen finish will replace the cardstock tableaus found in the base game.

4 x New "Ringleader" cards - Informants are a new ringleader (every player starts with one of each of the ringleaders) that add an element of bluff and deception to the game.

With Informants in play, you can play any card face down and take the Informant action.  Any other player may challenge the Informant. When challenged, the active player reveals the card that was played. If that card is the Informant, the challenger must give the active player 2M ISK. If that card is not the Informant, no payments are due from any player to the active player, the challenger steals 2M ISK from the active player and gets to take the action on the card that was played.

Informants are a really fun addition to the game and totally fitting with the Dystopian Universe.

A set of these promo specialist cards.

You are Awesome - Bonus #1: 3 x The Security Specialist promo
You are Awesome - Bonus #2: 3 x Crooked Warden promo
You are Awesome - Bonus #3: 3 x Veteran promo
You are Awesome - Bonus #4: 3 x Underboss promo
You are Awesome - Bonus #5: 3 x Negotiator promo

name: Star Ship Battles
description: An adaptation of 2D ship combat rules for use with any size models.  Ships are constructed by using a formula table in the rulebook based on their relative size, weapons fit, arc of fire, speed, etc.  Models often used are from other systems and the rules create fun, engaging battles across a space grid in a short amount of time relative to other, more robust systems.

name: Colour Wheel
description: Colour Wheel is a simple to learn, easy to play card game that teaches ROYGBIV color theory. The object is to be the first to have no cards left in your hand. Players lay down cards to make an ever-expanding wheel, creating a unique work of art every time it's played.

name: Polar Rush!
description:
A fierce blizzard is fast approaching, but young Kaya and his friends are still fishing out on the ice far from their igloos! The little Inuit need to pack up and rush home as quickly as they can. However, their journey back is fraught with many dangers. Heavy snow and strong winds make it difficult for them to find the shortest route back, the ice beneath them could break apart at any time, and hungry polar bears are lurking nearby! Using clever planning and a keen memory, can you be the first to navigate your Inuit across the ice floes and back to the safety of their igloo?

In Polar Rush!, seven ice floe tiles are placed together on the table to form the game board. On each ice floe are seven different animals or items found in the arctic. Movement tiles are spread out face down on the table. On a turn, a player reveals a number of movement tiles one at a time based on the number rolled on the die. If he reveals a "seal" and a seal is adjacent to his current position, he must move his Inuit to the "seal" (even if it means he must move backwards); if a seal isn't nearby, he doesn't move.

The floes also feature special characters that can help (or hamper) a player's movement, so with clever planning your movement can be quite successful. For example, if you move to a sled, your next move doesn't need to be to an adjacent tile — but if you reveal a "crack" tile, you can separate the game board to create a water gap between the floes. The only way to cross this is to reveal a kayak tile. The first person to get his Inuit home wins!

Polar Rush! includes simplified rules for Inuit as young as five as well as more complex rules for older Inuit.

name: Agents of SECTOR
description:
To better combat the rising tide of terrorism and threats around the globe, a new commission has formed. Comprised of elite teams from several intelligence agencies of the United States, SECTOR is mandated with the front-line defense of freedom and liberty.

But someone has to lead this organization, and you plan on being the one chosen as Administrator. So be prepared to defend against espionage and sabotage… and to commit acts of both to come out on top!

Over 12 rounds (weeks), each player will choose to place their three agents to perform one of the following options:

Perform an Action
Work a Mission
Get Help from The Agency
Play a Resource
Appropriate Resources

Managing resources wisely and completing missions will gain you Merit Points.  Direct, make shady deals and even sabotage other agencies to become the best!  The best managed agency at the end of the 12th week/round is the person who has earned the most merit points.

name: Dragon Ball Z TCG (2014 edition)
description:
Panini America, the leading global publisher of licensed sports and entertainment collectibles, is bringing the popular Dragon Ball Z card game back to the market for the first time since 2004.
 The 2014 edition features more than 200 new cards, reprints of past fan favorites and is completely compatible with the original series. The new game was developed by Panini America Brand Manager Aik Tongtharadol, a former Dragon Ball Z world champion who also worked on the original Dragon Ball Z Trading Card Game, most recently in 2004.

name: Intendentes
description:
In this exciting game each player performs the role of a mayor of a large district of the province of Buenos Aires in Argentina Republic. As such, you must lay out and manage the resources of his district and try to grow as much as you can.

Each construction that takes place in the game has its advantages and disadvantages, possible to levy taxes or produce food, but also increase the risks of the district making it more prone to flooding, fire, or be unsafe. The population grows and reproduces. Keep her happy as much as you can.
Maintaining a balance between growth and lack of control is not easy.

Some districts in Argentina are really large, and among them may be several cities, towns and even large crop fields, ranches and farms.

Intendentes is a turn-based game. The game consists of 10 rounds, and each round turn is divided into 8 phases.

During the game each mayor takes "blocks" through auctions which are built in his district. Each block has its own characteristics, may be a village, a city, an agricultural field, industry, or a unique and special block.

Each of these blocks gives something to the district, ability to accommodate much population, collect taxes or produce food.

In return, each block increases the risk levels of the district, level of crime, fire and flood. These are common problems that affect a large districts of Argentina.

It's also imprtant building blocks police and firefighters to combat these problems.

Each mayor manages its population, distributed in the blocks and choose their destinations.

Also, "plans" which are actions that directly interfere on their own district or on a "neighbor" are acquired. Choosing the right time to use makes a difference.

In the course of time various events can affect all the mayors and depending on the level of risk that each district suffer, can be affected and prejudiced in their progress.

The way each mayor manage his district, impacts the discomfort of the population, it is even likely that the population is so upset that perform mass protests against us, affecting our splendor.

The objective of the game is to be the mayor with the district most splendid of all.

name: Mit Zippo durch Herten
description:
Mit Zippo durch Herten is an educational game for children and families that has players move through and discover the city of Herten, North Rhine-Westphalia.

The game board is a map of the city. Traffic lights can hinder movement and players need to reach colored spaces that are placed in key locations and places of interest within the city.
It is also possible for players to anwser "Herten allgemein" (Herten in general) cards or play event cards to gain benefits or hinder other players.

Each player has a secret goal, which has him or her gather a number cards of different colors. Each color corresponds to different institutions, from recreational facilities to public services. A player gains a card when he enters a space of the same color on the board and then correctly answers the question given on it.

In doing so, the players get to know the layout of the city and learn about locations, services and activities.

name: Dead Meat: Quarantine Zone America
description:
Dead Meat: Quarantine Zone America Dead Meat is an action-packed tabletop skirmish game, where human factions compete in the ruined wasteland of the zombie apocalypse.

Dead Meat is a 28mm, tabletop skirmish game set 4 years after a massive pandemic has toppled society and set man against man. While zombies are an ever-present threat, other groups of survivors pose a much greater danger – you’ll soon learn that the dead are the least of your problems.

This focus on battles between groups of survivors is one of the things that sets Dead Meat apart from many of the current offerings in the zombie game genre. While zombie-bashing is a lot of fun, the real horror of the genre comes from the lengths people are willing to go to in order to survive. Dead Meat brings this terrifying struggle to the tabletop.

The theme of personal horror goes beyond the game’s look and feel. The rules set has been crafted as a zombie survival game from the ground up, ensuring that each game has elements of drama, tension, and action that you have come to expect from the zombie genre.

name: Ardor
description:
Have you ever wanted to build from scratch, fine tune and then live your most erotic, intimate and romantic desires?

Ardor is an unique strategy sex card game that enables you to do it.

Compete to collect cards which will be the building blocks for your fantasy.

Win the first part of the game to decide which fantasy will come true.

Mix and match the collected cards for an experience filled with Ardor!

Enhance the cards for activities to take a naughty twist which you control at all times. You have complete freedom on enhancing the cards and you can even level up each card differently every time you play the game for a highly customizable experience.

There are thousands of possible combinations allowing you to craft unique and unforgettable experiences!

Ardor has two parts:
Win Your Fantasy is a card game in which you win points and cards.
Live Your Fantasy Create your fantasy using what you've won to control all the details of what will happen next.

description: 550 Questions about Food and Drinks from champagne to comfort food, party game

name: Evermore
description:
What began as a celebration ended in tragedy when a wizard's fiery display went awry. Now, through no fault of your own, you find yourself trapped in a time loop forced to live the same day over and over and over and over again. Your only hope lies in a wizard whose advertisement you stumbled across in your search for answers and knowledge. He has informed you that he can cast a spell, tailor made for just you, that can open a portal through space and time.

For the first time in a very long while there is a faint glimmer of hope on the horizon. All you have to do is figure out a way to locate the spell components that the wizard needs and manage your day efficiently so that you can gather them all in time...

Evermore is a card auction, set collection, dice rolling game in which 2 - 4 players will compete to gain the knowledge necessary to efficiently gather the required components to win the game.

name: Vistula-Oder-Berlin: the campaign in Poland and East Germany, 1945
description:
Vistula-Oder-Berlin: the campaign in Poland and East Germany, 1945 is a simulation for two or more players that simulate the 1945 campaign  in Poland and Eastern Germany from January to May.

Historically, the Soviet troops occupied Berlin in May 1945 and the third Reich collapsed. However if the Panzer Army, sent to the Hungarian Front, was defending the capital, the final result could have been different. On the other hand, if the Soviet forces besieging the fortified city of Königsberg had concentrated their fighting power in the center, the fight might have been bigger than historical.

The German army is specialized in mobile counterattacks by armored troops and the Soviet army has excellent breakthrough ability and large concentrating firepower.

Two scenarios: campaign (Deutschland Kaputt! January-May, from the Vistula-Oder operation to the fall of Berlin and Prague) and Der Katastrophe (January-March 1945).

1 turn = 2 weeks
1 hex = about 20 km
1 Unit = German Army: Battalion to Division, Soviet Army: Corps
Number of players = 2
Play time = 6 to 10 hours (depending on the scenario)

Components:

    308 pieces (12.5 mm square)
    One map (A1 size)
    One rule book (12 pages)


(adapted from Japanese website text)


The game system is similar to Hongrie 1944-1945 (Vae Victis #78, Command Japan #100) system.

name: Peregrinus: Santiago de Compostela
description:
The players are pilgrims that get lost in an old enchanted forest. In order to find the exit they have to collect the magical items watched by Meiga, Moura and Lobishome in their dwellings, but...be careful! one of the players is the Santa Compaña, who disguised like a pilgrim try to undermine its playmates' pursuit and turn them one by one in its allies.

Every player has a Character card that shows if it is a Pilgrim or the Santa Compaña. He can't show it to the other players. Each player will use Pathway cards to move around the board choosing every turn what card have to play (they can be steps, bridge or do not move). Every Pilgrim has to look for two item cards shown in his Character card. The item cards are kept in the creature dwellings. In order to gain these cards the Pilgrim has to pay life tokens to the keepers. 
In the meantime the Santa Compaña player, secretly, will use its cards to threaten the other players, steal their life tokens and finally convert them to its allies. The only way for the Pilgrims to save themselves is to discover who is the Santa Compaña, use defensive item cards to repel it or finally find the requested cards to open the magical door and escape, reaching Santiago de Compostela.

Peregrinus is a dynamic and amusing game where luck, teamwork, intuition and strategy are equally necessary in order to discover dangers, find out the correct magical items, leave the enchanted forest before being caught by the Santa Compaña and reach Santiago. So, dare to enter the forest?

name: Adjugé vendu
description:
The objective of Adjugé vendu  is to become the richest art collector before the close of the auction!

Players seek out the most unusual and rare paintings, buy, sell and collect them, participating on auctions but must be careful because some items are copies!

The game also has electronic detector for detecting the false paintings!

If there are not paintings left the player with the most money is the winner.

name: Greedy Billionaire and the College Student
description:
This is a card game where players are College Students trying to graduate before the Greedy Billionaire can take away all their money.  They start with a supply of money and will need to pay tuition and other expenses each year (round).  They score points for graduating and for avoiding bankruptcy.  The Greedy Billionaire is not an actual player but he scores points for each College Student that goes bankrupt.

Players graduate by playing 4 Pass Exam cards (one each for freshman, sophomore, junior and senior year) and one Graduation card.  In order to obtain enough money to pay tuition, players may play action cards to get a job, earn a scholarship and receive financial aid.  But beware!  Their opponents will play Greedy Billionaire Cards to send their job overseas, raise tuition, cut the education budget, pollute the earth, and accuse them of cheating.

Points are tallied at the end of each hand and the final object is to be the first player to score 150 points in several hands of play.

name: Stranger Danger
description:
Stranger Danger is a card game for daring people in public places. Challenge your friends to approach a person in the crowd and discover what strangers will do to help you win.

On your turn, draw Stranger cards to describe a person to perform a challenge with. Then select from the Challenge cards you are given by the players on either side of you. To earn points, predict how the stranger will answer a Question or convince them to perform a Request.

name: Switch: The Game of Ups and Downs
description:
Switch is the exciting game in which three to five players race to play cards in sequence. But watch out! Letters and numbers can go up, down, or stay the same... and switch at any time. Be the first player out of cards and win!

Switch (the predecessor to Qwitch) consists of a deck of 64 cards, each containing one of eight numbers (1–8) and one of eight letters (A–H), and a die with plus, minus, and equals symbols. After hands are dealt, one player turns a card from the deck face up and rolls the die. Players race to play the next card from their hands, determined by the symbol on the die.

name: Her mit dem Schatz!
description:
The game is played with 12 treasure tiles and a six-sided die. The front of the tiles show various treasures: crown, genie lamp, or goblet. Each tile has one, two, or three treasures of the same type. To start the game, all twelve tiles are placed face down in the playing area.

Three faces of the die show a crown, lamp, and goblet; the other three show the numbers one, two, and three. Players take turns rolling the die, then must turn over a tile with either the same type of treasure (if a treasure was rolled) or the matching number of treasures (if a number was rolled). If the treasure matches, the player keeps it and places it face down in front of her.

Instead of turning over a tile in the center of the playing area, the active player may turn over a tile belonging to an opponent. If the tile matches, the player may steal it and take it into her own area.

name: Prima Ballerina
